div1.p: This is a draft of Carter's letter to Ferrell (August 25, 1922), which includes Carter's signature.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to John A. Ferrell, August 25, 1922
div1.opener:
File
Malaria (Problems)
(Ferrell)
New Glasgow P. O.,
Amherst County, Va.
“Geddes,” August 25, 1922
Dr. John A. Ferrell,
Director for the United States,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Ferrell:
div1.p:
Your letter of July 26/22, addressed to me at Marion, N. C., just
to hand.

In answer to your request for suggestions of field studies or
demonstrations of malaria which it seems advisable to make I would name
the following:
1) A study of the effect of impounding water on the incidence of malaria.

This study was begun in 1914 and carried on, during 1915 and 1916,
by LePrince: Griffitts and myself. Some surveys, minor, but not with-
out value, have been made by Griffitts and myself since that time and
the study suggested would be in continuation (completion?) of the work
already done.

The problem is of much economic and sanitary importance and I
think that a moderate amount of work for not less than two years and a
much smaller amount, as inspection and observation only, continued for
some years longer, (how many I cannot say) would be well repaid.

I have been purposing, when I have a little more data on this
subject and some spare time, to write up the findings we have been able
to arrive at so far and especially to formulate the measures advisable
for preventing, or at least minimising, malaria caused by making these
large ponds. A good deal of data for this purpose is already available.
& I hope to get a little more this fall.

The general method of study for the first two years would be
(a) select a location in which a large body of water will be impounded
impounded
2.
within a year or two--a hydro-electric plant in the making is the best
possible--(b) Make a survey (1) of the incidence of malaria in this
section: (2) of the Anopheles production, noting breeding places: species
and prevalence in residences.

These surveys should not only cover the flowage area of the pur-
posed pond, but should extend, roughly, a mile or mile and a half be-
yond the flowage contour--indeed, the survey, especially as to the spe-
cies of Anopheles and the production in this area beyond the contour
should be especially noted.full.

There is no need of including the whole of the area indicated
in the survey; this might involve a very large amount of work. It is
sufficient that cross-sections be taken, a half mile to a mile wide, at
suitable places so as to sample the country we are investigating. This
limitation is especially advised for the Anopheles survey. The malaria
survey is so much easier made that this may, except in very large ponds--
that of Lock 17, Black Warrior--was over 65 miles long--be made to in-
clude all people in the area indicated.

An examination of the same territory--after the pond is filled
and for as many years thereafter as may be necessary--should give us
data to determine the effect of the impounded water on the incidence
of malaria: Naturally, there are a number of other factors to be noted,
but this is the general plan.

Detail, and modifications advisable, of the above general plan
should be given only if this study be undertaken as it would involve
some time to write them out.

The above was what was planned and, more or less imperfectly, car-
ried out in 1915 and 1916.

A working party should consist of a chief (man of status of
Barber or Griffitts) with two or three intelligent young men for helpers
helpers (
3.
(students on vacation are about the type needed) and a Ford automobile.
This is for the surveys of areas before the water is impounded. After
the pond is filled, the use of a motor boat--usually cheaply obtain-
able from the Power Company--and one or two small skiffs or canoes are
necessary in addition. The skiffs should be furnished with Evenrude
motors.

One such party should be able to examine for two large ponds and
transportation between them must be provided for several trips

The work will last only during the season of contaminative Ano-
pheles production--May 1st. -October 31st. as a maximum: mainly from
June 1st.-Oct 31st.

The cost I cannot estimate. A guess estimate would be about
$12,500 to $15,000.00 each year for the first two years and about 67%
to 50% of that amount for--say five years thereafter--not necessarily
consecutive years.

The estimate is for one party with three assistants, working--
the Chief twelve and the assistants 6 1/2 months.

It is possible enough that the intensive work outlined for the
first two years would need to be repeated--so as to cover at least four
large ponds--in which case the larger estimate should hold for four years.
2) Study of Cypress swamp breeding of Anopheles.

This involves, and unquestionably includes, a study of such
breeding at a distance from the blood-supply furnished by man and domestic
animals.

I had purposed to take this up, in a small way, in 1917, but the
war prevented. It is of some importance, both from a scientific and a
practical standpoint, but especially from the former. Of much less im-
portance than (1), but is an absolutely untouched problem.
problem.

Estimate of cost--about $12,500.00 to $15,000.00 per annum--or
rather less--for--say--two years. Same field party as for Impounded
Water, but no launch needed.

3) To determine the different valencies in nature of our three
principal species of Anopheles as vectors of malaria.

Dr. Fricks is already working on this problem, as regards the
role of A. punctipennis compared with the other two, but I am sure he
would be glad to be able to extend this work.

It is obviously most important. Indeed, I have considered it
the most important of the field problems of malaria yet unsolved, and
have done some epidemiological (field) work on it myself.

The methods and costs of carrying them out can be obtained from
Dr. Fricks better than from myself. The expense will depend, naturally,
on the extent to which the work is carried.

4) To study how best to combine control of malaria (control
of Anopheles production?) with the large scale drainage projects for
agriculture.

I think this is not in the class of studies to which your letter
refers. It is, however, important and, I am sure, feasible.

Obviously, both the efficacy of the Anopheles control and the
economical adaptation of the measures therefor to the drainage work,
must be considered. It should begin by a preliminary study, in the
field where drainage work is going on, by a thoroughly competent malarial
engineer in consultation with a drainage engineer. During this, the
measures tentatively agreed on by both as necessary to control Anophe-
les production and allowable from a drainage standpoint could be checked up.

Practically the only expenses for this preliminary work would be
the pay of the malaria engineer and his travelling expenses--for he
should visit more than one drainage project. It would need one of the
of the
5.
very best of our engineers, however.

If this should result in the general adoption of measures for
the control of Anopheles by drainage engineers, and it might well be
an important step thereto, its value would be very great. We have been
trying since 1917 to get these men interested in malaria control, so
that the lands fitted for agriculture by drainage might be, by the same
measure, freed from malaria: This has not, by any means, always been
the case.

The repetition, in various places and times, of Mitzmain's
work at Monroe, La., in 1917, to determine the last date in the fall at
which Anopheles are infective to men.

This is important, as giving us the date in the fall at which it
is safe to suspend oiling and other measures for the control of Anophe-
les production. I think the saving to my Service in 1918, due to this
knowledge, was not less than $150,000.00.

This is a purely scientific study--partly field and partly bench--
and a working party should consist of one entomological microscopist and
a helper. More than one party can be used--and for several years.

This work, however, as it can be done for only about one month
per annum in any one district, had best be made a side issue to other
work of the same kind--such as Barber and Mayne are doing now. I doubt
then if this falls in the category of the class of studies you mean. I
think not.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, (Signed) H. R. Carter Address
New Glasgow P. O.,
Amherst Co., Va.
“Geddes.”
